bibl.title: Letter from Lawrence Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 7, 1900

div1.p: Lawrence Reed describes New Year's parties at two Cuban sugar plantations. He laments Bessie's marriage.

div1.head: Letter from Lawrence Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 7, 1900
div1.p:
Your letter of
the 31st reached me yesterday
and I am a thousand
times obliged for the things
you sent me, I imagine
you sent them in care
of the Transportation Q.m.
Pier 22 Brooklyn, if so they
will come on the transport
due this week. I wrote
Blossom about the handkerchiefs
DidEnt she get my letter?
They were so well worked and
I am so glad she is fond
of such work.

Well dearest I must tell
you of the royal time we
had on the 31st, Mr & Mrs
Pomvert who own one of
the prettiest plantations
in Cuba, gave a very swell
dance to their niece Miss
Terry whose father owns another
plantation about 16 miles from
them, this plantation of Mrs
Pomverts (she owns it) is called
Homogarous. We left the post
about 7 p.m. and when we reached the station
where a special train was waiting
we found 3 cars packed with Cubans & Spaniard
and among them some very pretty girls- We
reached the plantation at 8.45 and spent
about an hour visiting the sugar mills which
had begun grinding- Then the dance began
Supper was served just as the new year began
and it was a supper to behold- why Champagne
flowed like water & wines were common- I
truly dont believe it could be reproduced for less
than $1000.

The Miss Terry to whom the dance was
given was educated in France and speaks English
fluently- she is decidedly the prettiest& most
attractive somebody I have seen in Cuba. I
had two or three dances with her and in return
was asked to call at Carasses.
Carasses is the name of her
fathers plantation.- Well
the dance continued until 5.30
(which is the cuban costu
custom,) and we reached the
post in time for breakfast.
fortunately the next day was
New Year & I went to bed
and slept from 9. until 2.30
then turned in early that
night & slept from 8 until
8 the next morning-

Yesterday morning I got up
at 5.20 a.m. put on my “bestest”
cought the 611 a.m. boat. & left
Cienfuegos at 8.a.m. for Carasses.
I got off at Crusus about 31
miles from Cienfuegos & was
met with a special car, which
carried me to the home some
5 miles from Crusus. This plantation
is not quite as pretty as Homo
garous, because the Terry's have
been in France for 5 years.
but it is the largest & richest
in Cuba- they turn out 150.000
bags a season which means
48,750,000. lbs of sugar the
total value of which is $1,218,750.00
a clear profeit of $200 000.00 a year. We
sat down to breakfast at 10 & got up at 12.30
after about 15 courses. Then we went all over
the mill & I was explained the process in every
detail- I finally got back at 11.20 pm
& turned in for a good rest, after a long but
very pleasant sleep.

I hope Cooke will see you
before he leaves Georgetown, He is such a
nice fellow.

Seems to me you see Bessie
quite frequently I often wonder if she and Terry
are really to be married- I truly hope not
for I think too much of her for her to marry
someone else- Will look up the lace
div1.closer:
Best love to all from your
devoted Son Lawrence.
